user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_QueuePut_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_QueuePut_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, const void *data, size_t size, uint32 flags)
{
    int32                            return_code;
    int                              result;
    struct timespec                  ts;
    OS_impl_queue_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_queue_table, *token);

    /*
     * NOTE - using a zero timeout here for the same reason that QueueGet does ---
     * checking the attributes and doing the actual send is non-atomic, and if
     * two threads call QueuePut() at the same time on a nearly-full queue,
     * one could block.
     */
    memset(&ts, 0, sizeof(ts));

    /* send message */
    do
    {
        result = mq_timedsend(impl->id, data, size, 1, &ts);
    } while (result == -1 && errno == EINTR);

    if (result == 0)
    {
        return_code = OS_SUCCESS;
    }
    else if (errno == ETIMEDOUT)
    {
        return_code = OS_QUEUE_FULL;
    }
    else
    {
        /* Something else went wrong */
        return_code = OS_ERROR;
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_QueuePut_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_impl_queue_internal_record_t OS_impl_queue_table[OS_MAX_QUEUES]
...
typedef struct
{
    mqd_t id;
} OS_impl_queue_internal_record_t
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_QUEUE_FULL (-9)
...
#define OS_ERROR (-1)
...
typedef int32_t   int32
...
typedef uint32_t  uint32
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No unreachable code fragments were identified in the provided function. Reasoning:

- The do/while loop (mq_timedsend retry on EINTR) is reachable and required: the body executes at least once and the loop may repeat while result == -1 and errno == EINTR.
- After the loop there are three mutually exclusive outcomes that are all potentially reachable:
  - result == 0 (successful send) is reachable when mq_timedsend succeeds.
  - result == -1 with errno == ETIMEDOUT is reachable if the timed send times out (the code intentionally uses a zero timespec to force a non-blocking attempt / immediate timeout in some implementations).
  - result == -1 with some other errno is reachable for other error conditions (EINVAL, EBADF, EMSGSIZE, EAGAIN, etc.), so the final else branch is reachable.
- The OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET usage and OS_ObjectIndexFromToken invocation do not introduce unreachable code; they compute an index and fetch the table entry and are executed before the loop.
- There are no subsequent statements after an unconditional return that would make code unreachable in this function.

Given these points, there are no obvious unreachable code fragments to flag for MISRA C Rule 2.1 investigation.
